div1.p: As a Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Columbia and County of Washington begun and held in and for the County of Washington at the City of Washington on the first monday of June being the <gap extent="one word" reason="strikethrough" seventh day of the same month in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirteen and of the independence of the United States the 37th.

The Honorable
Wiliam Cranch esq. Chief Judge
Nicholas Fitzhugh
Buckmen Thrusten Esq. Assistant Judge
Washington Boyd Esq. Marshal
William Brent, Clerk
In the record of proceedings of the same Court among them is the following tort.
John Davis, Therese Davis, and Mary Davis Petitioners
against
Hezekiah Wood, Defendants
Be it remembered that heretofore to wit on the twenty sixth day of January in the year of our Lord Eighteen hundred and thirteen the following writ of the United States was <gap extent="one word" reason="strikethrough" filed in the Office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Columbia and County of Washington towt, "United States of America SS. The President of the United States, to the Judges of the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Columbia in the County of Washington Greetings: Whereas lately in the Circuit
Court of the United States for the District of Columbia in the County of Washington in a cause wherein John, Terese, and Mary Davis were plaintiff, or petitioners, and Hezekiah Wood was defendant on a petition for freedom judgement was rendered by the said Circuit Court for the said plaintiff, or petitioners by the inspection of the Transcript of the record of the said Circuit Court which was brought into the Supreme Court of the United States, agreeably to the Act of Congress in such case made and provided fully and at large appears. And whereas in the Term of Takeaway in the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred and twelve the said cause came on to be heard before the said Supreme Court on the said Transcript of the record of the said Circuit Court and was argued by counsel, on consideration whereof. It is the opinion of the Court that the said Circuit Court erred in giving the direction prayed by the counsel for the petitioners. It is-therefore adjudged ordered and decreed that the judgement of the said Circuit Court in the case be and the same is hereby reversed and annulled, and the said cause is hereby remanded to the said Circuit Court for further proceedings to be had therein according to law. and the same is hereby remanded accordingly. You therefore are hereby commanded that such proceedings be had in said cause as according to right and justice and the Laws of the United States, and agreeably to the said opinion and judgment of teh said Supreme Court- ought to be had, the said writ of error notwithstanding. Wittness the Honorable John Marshall Chief Justice of Said Supreme Court, this first monday in August, in the year of our Lord one
thousand eight hundred and twelve,
E.B. Caldwell, Clerk, Sup. Ct. U.S
And now here at the day to wit the first monday of June 1813 comes again into Court here as well <gap extent="one word" reason="strikethrough" the said <gap extent="three words" reason="Strikethrough" by Edmund L. Lee and James S. Morsell Esquire, their attornies as the said Hezekiah Wood by Walter Jones Lund &amp Thomas S. Key his attornies Whereupon for trying the issue joined between the parties aforesaid. It is ordered by the Court here that twenty persons from the panel of petit jurors returned to teh Court here by the Marshal of the District aforesaid be drawn by ballot according to the act of Assembly in such case made and provided, and thereupon the twenty persons being so drawn by ballot, and written upon two lists one of which said lists is delivered to the Counsel for the respective parties, and the counsel for each of the said parties having others out for persons from the said lists, thereupon the remaining twelve persons bring called come towrt: Archabald Lee William Duvall, Benjamin Bryar, Lehiel Crassfield, George StClair, Thomas Reynolds, Jeremiah Mudd, Walter B. Beall, Joseph Clarke, Joseph Ward, Alexander McCormick, and William Emack, who being enpannelled, and sworn to say the truth in the promise, upon their oath do say, that <gap extent="one word" reason="strikethrough" the said John Davis, Terese Davis, and Mary Davis are not free as they by their petition aforesaid have alleged. Therefore it is considered by the Court here that the said Hezekiah Wood go thereof without delay and soforth
Wits. Wm. Brent Clerk. Memorandum Before the jurors aforesaid returned from the Bar of the Court here to consider of and upon their verdict aforesaid the said John Davis, Terese Davis, and Mary Davis by their attornies aforesaid filed in Court here this following
Bill of exceptions which is signed sealed and <gap extent="one word" reason="smudged ink" accordingly to the Act Assembly in such case made and provided and which is as follows towt,
John Davis
Terese Davis
Mary Davis
v.
Hezekiah Wood
Memorandum, upon the trial of this cause the Petitioenrs offered to prove by competent witnesses that they the said witnesses have heard old persons who are now dead declare that a certain Mary Davis now dead, was a white woman born in England, and such was the general report in the neighborhood where the said Mary Davis lived- and also offered the same kind of testimony to prove that Susan Davis the mother of the petitioners was lineally descended in the female line from the said Mary Davis, and it was admitted that the said Susan Davis was at the time of the commencement of this petition for and acting in all respects as a free woman which evidence by hearsay and general reputation as aforesaid the Court reused to admit-except so far as it was applicable to the facts of pedigree of the petitioners to which refusal the petitioners except and this their bill of exceptions is signed sealed and enrolled this sixth July 1813.
W. Cranch Seal
N. Fitzhugh Seal
John Davis
Therese Davis
Mary Davis
v.
Hezekiah Wood
In the trial of this cause the petitioners to support the issue on their part joined proved that the petitioners are the Children of Susan Davis that the said Susan Davis is the same person named in the following record (here insert it) they their offered to read the said record in evidence to the Jury as prima facie evidence that the said petitioners are the descendants of the
female line from a free woman who was born free and are of free condition connected with the fact that the defendant in this case sold the said Susan Davis to Coll. Susan the person- mentioned as the defendant in the aforesaid record, But the Court refused to suffer the petitioners to read the said record to the jury as evidence in this cause. To which refusal the petitioners except &amp this their bill of exceptions is signed sealed and enrolled this 6th of July 1813.
W. Cranch
N. Fitzhugh
And thereupon the said John Davis Terese Davis and Mary Davis by their attornies aforesaid pray on Appeal from the judgment aforesaid, so as aforesaid rendered to the Supreme Court of the United States and it is granted them whereupon the said John Davis, Terese Davis, and Mary Davis by their attornies aforesaid, filed in Court here a certain writing obligating commonly called an Appeal Bond and which is concurred in the following words cont. Throw all men by these present, that we Daniel Renner and Joel Brown are held and firmly bound unto Hezekiah Wood in the full and just sum of two hundred dollars to be paid to the said Hezekiah Wood certain attorney, executes, administers, or assigns: to which payment well and truly to be made, we bind ourselves, our heirs, executor, and administrator jointly and severally by those present, sealed with our seals and dated this twenty first day of February in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fourteen. Whereas lately at a Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Columbia in Washington County in June Term of said Court last past in a suit depending
in said Circuit Court wherein John, Terese, and Mary Davis were petitioners and Hezekiah Wood was defendant. Judgement was rendered against the said Petitioners and the said Petitioners having obtained a writ of error and filed a copy thereof in the Clerks office of the said Circuit Court to reverse the judgment in the aforesaid suit, and a citation directed to the said Hezekiah Wood citing and admonishing him to be and appear at a Supreme Court of the United States, to be holden at Washington on the first Monday of February instant. Now the condition of the above obligation is such, that if the said Petitioners shall prosecute their writ to effect and answer all damages and costs if they fail to make their plea good, the the above obligation to be void else to remain in full force and viewed.
sealed and delivered in presence of Robert Brent Thomas B. Gilpin
Danl. Renners Seal
Jack Brown Seal
which being read and heard and the securities in the said Bond being by the Court here approved it is therefore ordered by the said Court here that the record and proceedings aforesaid in the plea aforesaid, with all things thereunto relating be transmitted to the said Supreme Court of the United States; and the same are transmitted to the said Court accordingly.
Test. Wm. Brent clerk
United States
The President Of the Untied States
To the Judges of the Circuit Court of the United States for the district of:
Columbia in the County of Washington Greetings: Because in the record and proceedings as also in the rendition of the judgment of a plea which is in the said circuit court before you, or some of you, between: John, Terese, and Mary Davis Petitioners and Hezekiah Wood Defendant
a manifest error hath happened, to the great damage of the said Petitioners as by their complaint appears. We being willing that error, if any hath been, should be judly corrected, and full and speedy justice done to the parties aforesaid in this behalf: Do command you, if judgment be therein given , that then under your seal distinctly and openly, you send the record and proceedings aforesaid, with all things concerning the same to the Supreme Court of the United States, together with this writ, so that you have the same at Washington on the first Monday of February next, in the said Supreme Court, to be then and there held, that the record and proceedings aforesaid being inspected, the said Supreme Court may cause further to be done therein to correct that error, what of right and according to the law and custom of the United States should be done. Witness, the honorable John Marshall chief justice of the said Supreme Court, this First Monday of August in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirteen and of the Independence of the Untied States the thirty eighth.
B. Caldwell Clk. Sup. Ct. U.S

District of Columbia Towrt: At a Circuit Court of the District of Columbia begun and held in and for the County of Washington at the City of Washington on the fourth monday of december being the Monday sixth day of the same month in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and Eight , and of American Independence the thirty third.
Honorable
WIlliam Cranch Esquire, chief judge
Nicholas Fitzhugh
Allen B. Duckett, Esquire Assistant Judge
Washington Boyd Esquire Marshal William Brent Clerk
In the Record of proceedings of teh same Court, amongst others in the following To wit.
Susan Davis, Then Daughter, Against Caleb Swann
Be it remembered that heretofore towt on the fourth day of September in the year of our lord one thousand Eight hundred and seven the said Susan and any by Henry Robert their attorney filed in Court here the following petition to the Honbl. the judges of the Circuit Court of the County of Washington in the District of COlumbia, the humble Petn. of Susan Davis &amp her daughter Amy humbly showeth that your petitioners are detained in slavery by Caleb Swann &amp as they were born free, they pray that prcoess may be awarded
to compell the appearance of the said Caleb Swann to answer their complaint
H. Hiort for Complle.
14th Sept. 1809
Whereupon a suit of the United States of subpoena issued to the marshal of the District of Columbia, in the words and of the letter following, this is to say: "District of Columbia Court: The United States of America to the marshal of the District of Columbia, Greetings: You are hereby commanded to summon Caleb Swann that all excuses and delays set aside he be and appear before teh Circuit Court of the District of Columbia, to be held in and for the County of Washington at the City of Washington on the fourth monday of december next then and there to answer the petition of negro Susan Davis and her daughter Amy in the said Court exhibited against him for their freedom. Hereof fail not at your peril and have you then and there this writ. Witness William Cranch, Esq. Chief Judge fo the said Court the 31st day of August 1807. heard the 21st day of September 1807. Hiort. Wm. Brent Clerk. At which said Fourth monday of december being the Twenty eigth day of the same month in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and seven, and the return day of the aforegoing writ of subpoena come into the Circuit Court here, the said Susan and Amy by their
said attorney; and the marshal of the District of Columbia aforesaid, to whom the said Subpoena was in form aforesaid decided, makes return thereof to the Court here, thus endorsed
Swn. 4th Sept. 1807
Danl. Brent marshal. and the said Caleb Swann being called appears in court here by Francis S. Key and Elias B. Caldwell his attornies: whereupon the Court here, on motion of the said Petitioners by their said attorney orders the said Caleb Swan to enter unto recognization in the sum of eight hundred dollars current money, conditioned that the said Caleb Swan, do not remove the said petitioners out of the District of Columbia nor obstruct them from attending this court from time to time in support of their said petition; Thereupon the said Caleb Swann present here in court, acknowledges himself to owe and stand justly in debted unto the United States of America in the sum of Eight hundred dollars current money to be levied up his body goods and chattels. consideration to and for the use of the United States on condition that he the said Caleb Swan do not remove Susan Davis and her daughter Amy out of the District of Columbia no obstruct them from attending this court from time to time, in support of their petition for freedom exhibited in the said Court against him the said Caleb Swan and in the mean time to feed cloath and see them well. And thereupon, on motion of the said Petitioners by their attorney aforesaid, it is ruled by the Court here that the
said Caleb Swan answer to the petition aforesaid, of the said petitioners on the plea aforesaid or judgment by the Court here will be remembered against him by defailt, and the said Caleb Swan by his said attornies, defends the force and injury when to and prays leave of the Court here to imparte untill the first monday of June next to answer to the petition of the said Petitioners in the plea aforesaid and he hath it, the same day is given, to the said petitioners then vc. At which mentioned first monday of June being the sixth day of the same month in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and eight untill which day the said Caleb Swan had lease to imparts and then to answer to the Petition of the said Petitioners in the plea aforesaid, come as well the said Petitioners by their said attorney; as the said Caleb Swan by his said attorney. Thereupon further process of and upon the premises aforesaid between the parties aforesaid by counsel of said parties, and their attornies aforesaid and by laws of the Court herethereon is further continued untill the fourth monday of december next. And now here at the day towrt. the fourth monday of December being the twenty sixth day of the same month in the year of our Lord one thousand Eight hundred and eight come again into the Circuit Court for as well the said Petitioners by Henry Hurt and Walter Jones Junner their attornies: as the said Caleb Swan by his attornies aforesaid. And the said Caleb Swan by his said attornies come and defends the force and injury when he and says that the
the said Susan and her daughter Amy are the proper slaves of him the said Caleb without that that the said Susan &amp Amy are free women &amp of free condition &amp that he is ready to verify, wherefore he pray sjudgment if the said Susan &amp Amy &amp their action aforesaid to have or maintain ought by anything before by the said Caleb in pleadings alleged , they ought not to be precluded from having said maintaining their action aforesaid against the said Caleb, because protesting, that they are not slaves, but are free born, and this they pray may be enquard of by the Country he and the said Caleb in like manner &amp c. Therefore let a jury therefore appear before the Court here immediately by when &amp c and who neither &amp c to recognize &amp c Because as well &amp c who being calleld come that is to say- James Veitch, Charles King, Alexander C. Sncherez, Jeremiah Boothe, David Wharn, Griffith Coonber, John Hollinghead, Adam Lindsay, Nicholas L. Queens, George Moore, Nathanial Newton and to him thereupon who being Subpoenaed and worn to say the truth in the premises upon their oath do say, that they find for the Petitioners; Therefore It is considered by the Court here, that the said Susan davis and her daughter Amy, the petitioners aforesaid, recover their freedom of and against the said Caleb Swan and that they before and discharged of and from the service of the said Caleb Swan and that they Therese Susan Davis and her daughter Amy go thereof freed and
discharged without delay &amp c. It is also considered by this Court here, that the said Susan Davis and her daughter Amy recover against the said Caleb Swan the sum of thirty seven dollars sixty two and one half cents and the quantity of one hundred and Eighty six pounds of tobacco by the Court here unto the said Susan Davis &amp c her daughter Amy, adjudged on their assent for their costs and charge by them about the <gap extent="one word" reason="strikethrough" prosecution of their petition aforesaid did out and expended and that they have thereof their of their execution, &amp c. Memorandum, judgement rendered in this cause for the petitioners for their freedom and costs of prosecution on the eighteenth day of January Amno Domini One thousand Eight Hundred and Nine-Wm. Brent Clerk.
